Award.AwardTitle: Engineering the regioselectivity of Baeyer-Villiger monooxygenases
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Stefan Lutz from Emory University to create novel biocatalysts for Baeyer-Villiger oxidation with enhanced regio-selectivity. Catalysts not only facilitate chemical reactions in industrial processes as diverse as producing petrochemical fuels and manufacturing pharmaceuticals, but they also govern the chemistry of life, playing a key role in driving biochemical reactions in cells. A better understanding of the fundamentals of (bio)catalysts, as well as advances in synthetic biology and biotechnology now allow scientists to manipulate and tailor biocatalysts for properties such as stability and recognition of new substances. These capabilities have created unprecedented opportunities to adapt these highly efficient and renewable catalysts for novel, unnatural functions needed in industrial applications, thereby creating new, safer and more sustainable processes. This project will provide graduate students with specialized training in preparing biocatalysts, as well as tailoring them to specific industrial applications. It also introduces undergraduate researchers, as well as high school teachers and students to the concepts of biocatalysis and green chemistry.

The area of flavo-enzyme engineering for utility in synthetic chemistry is one that is ripe for development. Directed enzyme 'evolution' is a burgeoning field, but this enzyme class is relatively underexplored, and yet holds great potential for application to chemistry of interest. Employing a combination of flavin cofactor analog substitution and protein mutagenesis, native monooxygenases will be tailored for effective and selective conversion of asymmetric ketones to the corresponding ester regio-isomers. Lead candidates among these engineered enzymes will be characterized via comprehensive biochemical and biophysical analysis. These studies will provide detailed information concerning the impact of various engineering strategies and assist in developing accurate predictive frameworks for future enzyme redesigning endeavors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of enzymes as biocatalysts is a rapidly emerging field, offering a green and sustainable way for producing high value fine chemicals and pharmaceutical products. The growth in the area has been particularly benefited from advances in molecular biology, allowing scientists and engineers to tailor natural enzymes for specific industrial applications. 

As part of our NSF-sponsored research, we have explored different protein engineering strategies to tailor the function of enzymes that catalyze Baeyer-Villiger oxidations. These enzymes named Baeyer-Villiger monooxygenases (BVMOs) can utilize molecular oxygen to efficiently and stereoselectively oxidize ketones to ester intermediates. Of particular interest are Baeyer-Villiger oxidations of asymmetric keto substrates which can lead to formation of two distinct regio-isomers. In contrast to traditional, chemical oxidation reactions where the ratio of regio-isomers is determined by the substrate’s reactivity (precisely by the nature of substituents flanking the keto group), BVMOs are not strictly limited to chemical reactivity. Instead, these biocatalysts can modulate the trajectory of the oxygen insertion reaction and give access to the chemically less favorable regio-isomer. Such control over product formation is highly desirable for the efficient chemical synthesis of target molecules.

The results of our three-year study have: a) demonstrated that the regio-selectivity of BVMOs can be effectively tailored to a particular substrate and to producing a desired isomer, and b) offered new insights into the fundamentals of regio-selectivity in this family of enzymes. Applying a combination of amino acid substitutions and deletions, we were able to identify enzyme variants with almost 10-fold increased catalytic activity for known and novel substrates. The same protein engineering strategies also gave control over formation of either regio-isomer with selectivity as high as 98%. More importantly, stereoselectivity could be tuned equally well towards the chemically favorable and unfavorable products. Furthermore, structure models and kinetic studies have offered insights into mechanistic details of the enzymatic process which are proving foundational for the development of a predictive framework for functional gains in connection with future BVMO engineering efforts.

Beyond the scientific merits of the work, the project has offered an intellectual framework for laboratory team members at all stages of their professional training. The challenges of protein engineering and the implementation of the subsequent biochemical studies required extensive collaboration and the success reflects effective teamwork of all parties involved. The broader community has also benefited from this work through publications and the oral dissemination of our findings by team members at the local, national and international level. Finally, outreach activities including STEM education activities at the K-12 level in the greater Atlanta area. Separately, the entire research team has become an active participant in the annual Atlanta Science Festival Expo. The day-long event held in Piedmont Park each spring attracts over 20,000 visitors and offers a wonderful opportunity to engage the broader public and to share the nature, implications and potential impact of our NSF supported research.
